v  vi  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
At the request of the Knowledge and Learning Board (KLB), the World Bank Institute Evaluation Group (WBIEG) evaluated the staff learning program provided by the Environmentally and Socially Sustainable Development (ESSD) network in FY05 and FY06. The study focused on helping the network understand its accomplishments vis-à-vis staff learning, address weaknesses, and improve the relevance, effectiveness, and impact of ESSD's learning program in the future. WBIEG collected and analyzed data from members of ESSD's learning team, network staff, sector managers, Bank data systems, and assessments of quality by participants in ESSD learning events.
STAFF LEARNING PROVIDED BY ESSD
Integration of knowledge sharing and learning into ESSD's business. The composition of ESSD's knowledge-sharing and learning (KSL) team fosters collaboration across the network's departments and units, and the team works cohesively to identify and address strategic priorities. Major centralized initiatives to guide, support, and monitor the network's KSL program in FY05 and FY06 included assessments of knowledge and learning needs and preferences and ongoing tracer studies of selected programs. The team also demonstrated a commitment to transparency, developing and maintaining a KSL site on the intranet. Despite such effort, focus groups and interviews with regional managers revealed limited awareness of the network's learning program.
The scope and scale of ESSD's learning program. The Bank's learning management system (LMS) indicated that ESSD was the main sponsor for 142 learning events in FY05 and 155 events in FY06. However, these data provided limited information on the overall learning program and did not include some important learning initiatives such as peer exchanges, KSL product grants, and a mentoring program. The network championed the synergy of learning and knowledge-sharing activities and products for staff, and the program in FY05 included a coordinated series of offerings to develop the capacity of staff designing and organizing KSL initiatives. A portfolio of KSL products and online resources supplemented ESSD-related learning events in both years.
PARTICIPATION IN ESSD'S LEARNING PROGRAM
Patterns of participation. At least 75 percent of ESSD staff attended one ESSD- related learning event in FY05, and at least 60 percent did so in FY06. This decrease can be explained in part by the fact that ESSD week was offered in FY05 but not in FY06. The profile of ESSD participants underscored that the learning program must develop locally appropriate technical expertise for a staff based largely at headquarters but also located in many country offices, effectively serve senior staff, and cater to many people
vii  who were new to the Bank. Overall, staff mapped to the network participated in an average of 2.2 ESSD learning events in FY05 and 1.7 events in FY06. Staff based at headquarters, new to the Bank, or in ESSD's vice presidential unit (VPU) tended to participate in the most events each year.
Factors influencing participation. ESSD staff expected the learning program to serve a variety of functions, and a majority of participants indicated that the following goals were important or very important for motivating them to attend learning events: becoming aware of new ideas and emerging issues in their sector (94 percent); enhancing job performance in current position (93 percent); networking or sharing information (89 percent); developing core sector skills and knowledge (84 percent); and developing advanced, specialized sectoral knowledge (76 percent). The relative importance of these factors did not differ significantly between staff at headquarters and those in country offices, but several participants did express concern about the accessibility of the program for staff outside of Washington. In focus groups and interviews, managers reflected that the many demands of Bank operations often made it difficult for staff to attend learning events.
QUALITY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF ESSD'S LEARNING PROGRAM
Overall Quality. Insufficient information was available on the objectives of the learning program, the planned activities, and the events actually delivered to support an independent analysis of how well the program was aligned with the strategic priorities of ESSD's business plan. This evaluation therefore explored the program's quality and effectiveness by examining perceptions among ESSD-mapped staff and managers. Nearly two-thirds (65 percent) of ESSD-mapped participants in ESSD learning events indicated that the overall quality of the learning program was very good (17 percent) or good (48 percent). At the same time, however, a question asking survey respondents to describe concrete experiences with the learning program revealed that many of these participants did not know which events were offered as part of ESSD's KSL program. Average ratings from participants' assessments of the quality of individual events improved notably from FY05 to FY06, suggesting that the efforts to develop KSL capacity in FY05 were successful.
Relevance.Seventy percent of ESSD participants found the relevance of the learning choices to be very good (23 percent) or good (47 percent). Ratings were more positive among respondents in the ESSD VPU, but this dynamic could be explained by the focused emphasis during this period on developing the capacity of staff who design KSL initiatives.
Areas of Effectiveness. Ratings of the program's effectiveness were significantly higher for raising awareness of new issues (69 percent very good or good) and providing opportunities for networking (64 percent very good or good) than for developing core sector skills and knowledge (56 percent very good or good) or developing advanced, specialized sector knowledge (48 percent very good or good). These results indicate that the program was most effective in those areas that were deemed to be most important by participants. Identifying steps to increase program effectiveness will require the establishment of clear objectives for the learning program and communicating relevant
viii  events and products to managers and staff so that they know of opportunities to address their demands.
Satisfaction with learning design and delivery. Two-thirds of participants (67 percent) provided positive ratings (very good or good) for the organization of learning events, and 75 percent provided positive ratings for the quality of instructors or speakers. Again, respondents in the ESSD VPU provided higher ratings on average. These ratings signal the need for improvements since many participants (one quarter to one third) were not satisfied with design or delivery features. These generalizations about the program across two years may be of limited use given the indication by participants' assessments that quality increased notably from FY05 to FY06 and evidence that respondents could not necessarily differentiate between ESSD's staff learning program and those offered by other VPUs.
Use of skills and knowledge acquired in learning events. Two-thirds of ESSD participants (66 percent) reported using the skills and knowledge they gained in ESSD learning events frequently or very frequently. Participants were most likely to apply what they learned when the skills and knowledge were relevant to their current job responsibilities.
Suggestions for future learning from ESSD staff. Participants expressed a strong interest in attending learning events that would clarify the new organizational structure and work programs resulting from the consolidation of ESSD and the Infrastructure network into the Sustainable Development network (SDN). To improve the effectiveness of ESSD-related learning in the future, respondents emphasized the need to increase the involvement of country office (CO) staff in the learning program (both as providers and participants) and to improve the relevance of offerings.
CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS
Suggested Actions for the KSL Team
ESSD established centralized structures and processes to shape its overall learning program, and the findings of this evaluation did not signal the need for major changes to the current model. Recommended actions, in the order they should occur, include:
Knowledge and learning results framework. The lack of clear objectives for the learning program, detailed information on how planned activities supported learning objectives, and data on the delivery and content of learning events prevented a systematic analysis of how well the program's offerings supported the strategic priorities of ESSD's business plan. The KSL team should establish measurable objectives for its learning program with associated indicators to gauge how well the program is addressing the network's business needs.
Data management. Participants and ESSD learning events and sector managers all provided evidence that staff did not have enough timely information to choose and schedule appropriate learning offerings. To improve the quality and use of the LMS, standard guidelines should be established for entering learning activity data and a quality assurance process created to support improved data management.
ix  Accountability and continuous improvement. ESSD had various structures and strategies in place to incorporate evaluation findings into the planning, design, and delivery of learning activities. Nevertheless, findings from this study underscored the need for systematic monitoring and dissemination to support program improvements. The network's KSL team should clarify responsibilities and establish a cycle for incorporating formative guidance into its learning plan, sharing best practices among learning providers, and monitoring areas of potential weaknesses.
Suggested Actions for the CLO and the KLB
Steps to ensure that staff engage in effective ESSD-related professional and technical learning include:
Improvements to centralized systems. The CLO and KLB have actively supported the development of the LMS and the toolkit and template for creating learning plans. The experiences for ESSD's learning program suggest that the CLO's office should continue refining processes, definitions, and systems that support VPUs in developing and delivering staff learning. Findings from this evaluation can inform improvements to the learning plan toolkit and action steps for the LMS.
Fostering a community of practice. Just as ESSD's KSL team fosters efficiency and synergy in learning across the network's units, so should the KLB promote and facilitate collaboration and information sharing to support the new results agenda. A simple electronic learning community could supplement KLB meetings by sharing knowledge, tools, lessons learned, and other resources across VPUs. Such a platform would strengthen the centralized functions embodied by the KLB and allow VPUs to access and adapt each others' products or strategies to support the Bank's decentralized business.
x  1. INTRODUCTION
1.1 Effective staff learning is of critical importance to the World Bank to ensure that personnel have the best mix of skills, behaviors, experience, and technical expertise for achieving the Bank's business objectives. The Chief Learning Officer (CLO) and the Knowledge and Learning Board (KLB) work together to guide and oversee the overall staff learning program. Based on annual learning plans approved by the CLO, the six regions, 11 strategic learning centers (SLCs), and other VPUs provide learning activities that increase staff effectiveness within specific lines of business. The CLO manages a substantial investment in staff learning each year--$76.8 million in FY06--and works with the KLB to select certain programs to be evaluated by the World Bank Institute Evaluation Group (WBIEG). At the request of the KLB, WBIEG evaluated the overall learning program provided by the Environmentally and Socially Sustainable Development (ESSD) network in FY05 and FY06.
1.2 ESSD has shepherded the Bank's efforts to assist clients in achieving poverty reduction through sustainable development. An integrated approach to growth based on social and environmental responsibility is necessary for developing countries to overcome risks and vulnerabilities, and ESSD fosters this integration through a set of interrelated sector strategies on agriculture and rural development, forests, water resources, the environment, and social development. The network also advanced the sustainable development agenda through global partnerships such as with the Global Environment Facility and the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research (CGIAR) and through cross-sectoral work to strengthen the links with the water and sanitation, transportation, urban, energy, and rural development sectors.1
1.3 The broad reaching work of ESSD has required the synchronization of knowledge sharing, learning, and strategic staffing, and the network's learning plans in FY05 and FY06 focused on ensuring that staff had access to relevant knowledge-sharing and learning programs to support ESSD's strategic priorities. This evaluation focused on the overall ESSD learning program to help the network understand its accomplishments vis- à-vis staff learning and to improve the program's future relevance, effectiveness, and impact. The goal of the study was to provide the KLB and the network with information to guide strategic decisions about staff learning programs.

3  2. STAFF LEARNING PROVIDED BY ESSD
2.1 Since FY04, knowledge sharing has been increasingly embedded in ESSD's staff learning program. Specialists in professional and technical areas, learning, and information management collaborate to provide learning programs and knowledge products that support staff in conducting the network's business. The network's KSL team developed and implemented processes to support a comprehensive program for addressing the learning and knowledge needs of staff in FY05 and FY06. Unfortunately, this overall program was not yet accurately reflected in the Bank's learning management system (LMS) or well understood by regional managers.
INTEGRATION OF KNOWLEDGE SHARING AND LEARNING INTO ESSD'S BUSINESS
2.2 For FY05 and FY06, ESSD had formal structures to address staff learning and knowledge needs. These included a KSL oversight committee chaired by the network's Knowledge and Learning Coordinator and a KSL cross-departmental team to develop and implement an overall program of knowledge-sharing and learning initiatives (events and products) each year. By design, the composition of the team fostered collaboration within ESSD. Team members represented the three main families of social development, environment, and agriculture and rural development (ARD), the Quality Assurance and Compliance Unit responsible for safeguards, CGIAR, resource management, human resources, communications team (including external affairs), and ESSD information technology and advisory services.
2.3 KSL team members supported the Bank's decentralized business by working in their respective units to assess learning needs and identify priorities in line with business objectives. They also worked cohesively as a team, meeting regularly and sharing processes and practices to address the network's agreed-upon learning priorities. Major centralized initiatives to guide, support, and monitor the overall KSL program in FY05 and FY06 included assessments of knowledge and learning needs and preferences and tracer studies of some programs to track effectiveness. Common practices used by KSL team members to develop and implement the KSL program are described in box 2.1. The examples provided are not intended to present a comprehensive list of practices and tools across the three departments but do illustrate how different units use joint or parallel processes to design and deliver ESSD's learning program.
2.4 ESSD's KSL team demonstrated a commitment to transparency, developing and maintaining a central KSL page on the intranet for staff and also posting relevant KSL information on the intranet sites of individual ESSD departments. Through these online resources, network staff had access to knowledge products, descriptions of learning events, evaluation data, quarterly reports to the KLB, and contact lists for KSL team

2.5 Despite the efforts of the KSL team to develop a transparent learning program closely linked with network business needs, focus groups and interviews with regional managers revealed a lack of awareness about ESSD's learning program. In general, these managers equated the learning program with ESSD week and were not consistently familiar with other offerings. They also did not necessarily know how to learn about the ESSD learning program or whom to contact if they wanted to offer input. These findings indicated that the KSL team's internal processes for strategic planning and program development should include a comprehensive communications strategy to connect better with its network audiences.

2.7 The limited understanding about ESSD's program among managers was not surprising given that the learning program focused on crosscutting themes and offered content across all Bank operations. The program championed issues for sustainable development rather than targeting a static group of clients (described more in chapter 3), and the activities could not always be easily distinguished from those of other staff learning providers in the Bank. The need for more effective dissemination about ESSD learning activities was therefore part of a broader challenge wherein ESSD's KSL team did not yet benefit effectively from the Bank's larger staff learning infrastructure.
2.8 ESSD has championed the synergy of learning and knowledge-sharing activities and products for staff since FY04, sometimes at the forefront or even outside of the Bank's larger staff learning infrastructure. The Bank's Learning Board was not reconstituted into the KLB until FY06. The structure of the LMS in FY06 supported the recording of individual learning events but not the important contextual information showing how events connect into coherent programs. Bank-wide definitions for KSL
6  events remained elusive for ESSD's KSL team, causing the network to code activities and products within three tentative categories: knowledge generation, knowledge sharing and learning, and information management.
2.9 The challenges associated with Bank-wide definitions and structures provide important context for this evaluation in FY06 and are explored throughout this report. A key issue described in the next section is that no central information source accurately reflected ESSD's offerings and products, so managers and staff who did not know who offered learning focused on specific crosscutting themes would have difficulty identifying opportunities available through ESSD's learning program.

These were supplemented by nonformal, short-format sessions and a portfolio of KSL products. The learning program for FY05 focused in particular on building the capacity of ESSD's KSL staff, so that they, in turn, could develop effective KSL events and products for their constituencies in the future.

9  3. PARTICIPATION IN ESSD'S LEARNING PROGRAM
3.1 The business of sustainable development is crosscutting, and ESSD's learning program served staff throughout the Bank in FY05 and FY06. This evaluation explored the patterns of participation in the program and the factors that influenced whether staff attended ESSD learning events.4 Overall, staff mapped to ESSD demanded learning to address a broad range of goals--from becoming aware of new ideas and emerging issues in their sectors to developing advanced, specialized technical expertise. In both years, participation in ESSD learning was highest among staff who were based at headquarters, in the ESSD VPU, or new to the Bank.
PATTERNS OF PARTICIPATION
3.2 ESSD's learning program in FY05 served at least 3,406 nonunique participants, with 1,604 (47 percent) of these mapped to ESSD.5 The program in FY06 reached at least 3,812 nonunique participants, with 1,245 (33 percent) of these mapped to ESSD. This overview of participation provides insight into the reach of the program, targeting audiences throughout the Bank to advocate for sector-related issues and delivering training on safeguards across all Bank operations.

15  4. QUALITYAND EFFECTIVENESS OF ESSD'S LEARNING PROGRAM
4.1 This evaluation explored the quality and effectiveness of the network's learning program in FY05 and FY06 by examining perceptions among ESSD-mapped staff and managers in combination with participants' assessments of individual learning events. Major stakeholders were satisfied with the program's overall quality but also demonstrated an uncertainty about which learning events ESSD offered. Participants indicated on average that the program was most effective in providing opportunities for networking and raising awareness of emerging issues. Respondents in the ESSD VPU were generally more satisfied with the program's quality and relevance than regional staff.
OVERALL QUALITY
4.2 ESSD's learning plans for FY05 and FY06 emphasized that the objectives of the learning program were to support the strategic priorities of the ESSD business plan. For FY05, the learning plan included some measurable objectives such as "increase the number and improve the quality of cross-sector learning programs." The FY06 learning plan listed priority areas to support rather than measurable objectives and then presented "a brief profile of knowledge-sharing and learning activities to be offered by ESSD during FY06." The limited information available on the objectives of the learning program, the planned activities, and the events actually delivered across both years prevented an assessment of how well the program was aligned with the strategic priorities of the ESSD business plan as intended.
4.3 Given these limitations, focus group discussions with managers and members of ESSD's KSL team framed the context through which to examine the program's quality. The survey of participants then systematically explored the experiences of staff (including managers) with the learning program in FY05 and FY06. Survey respondents provided a summary rating of the program's overall quality, and nearly two-thirds (65 percent) rated the program as very good (17 percent) or good (48 percent) (figure 4.1). These ratings varied little among subgroups: the only notable difference was that respondents whose primary VPU was ESSD provided higher ratings on average than those from EAP or ECA.
4.4 An important consideration in reviewing the ratings of program participants is that respondents did not necessarily know which learning events had been offered as part of ESSD's KSL program. To explain better the overall assessments of quality, the survey questionnaire prompted respondents to describe one positive experience and one negative experience that they had had with ESSD's program in FY05 or FY06. Despite these instructions, comments from many staff reflected an understanding of staff learning as a

This lack of differentiation among learning programs is an important finding of this evaluation, with implications for the ratings on quality and effectiveness discussed throughout this chapter.

SATISFACTION WITH LEARNING DESIGN AND DELIVERY
4.16 Aside from feedback on content, participants of ESSD learning events provided ratings for the organization of events and the quality of speakers in the overall learning program in FY05 and FY06. Two-thirds of respondents (67 percent) characterized the organization of learning events (e.g., design and logistics) as very good (22 percent) or good (45 percent), and 30 percent rated this as fair. For the quality of instructors or speakers, 75 percent provided a rating of very good (26 percent) or good (49 percent), and 22 percent rated this as fair. These ratings signal the need for improvements since many participants (one quarter to one third) did not provide positive ratings for design or delivery features. Nonetheless, these generalizations about the program across two years may be of limited use given the indication by participants' assessments that quality increased notably from FY05 to FY06 and evidence that many respondents did not differentiate between ESSD's staff learning program and those offered by other VPUs.
4.17 An important function of any staff learning program is to provide information on planned activities to potential participants. Communication strategies must be tailored to attract the appropriate target audiences and implemented far enough in advance so that staff can fit learning into their schedules. The survey of participants explored this function of the learning program, and 55 percent of respondents indicated that the timeliness of information about upcoming learning offerings was very good (17 percent) or good (38 percent). Thirty-four percent indicated that the timeliness of information was fair.
4.18 ESSD's strategies for disseminating information on upcoming offerings seem especially important given that managers in focus groups and survey respondents in their comments both demonstrated limited awareness about the scope of the program beyond ESSD week. Respondents indicated how they learned about upcoming events by rating the effectiveness of various communication methods used by the ESSD learning team. As shown in figure 4.3, most respondents (94 percent) found e-mail announcements to be very effective or effective while less than one third (31 percent) provided these positive ratings for the learning management system or for ESSD's intranet KSL web page.

Beyond the emphasis on the transition to the SDN, comments frequently suggested learning topics that were not network-specific such as improving skills for writing or for monitoring and evaluation.
4.28 Finally, participants had the opportunity to offer other suggestions for improving the effectiveness of the learning program in the future. Two dominant themes emerged from the comments offered by 64 respondents:
Involve CO staff more in the learning program. Twenty-one respondents suggested increasing the opportunities available for CO staff by offering more study tours, strategically selecting country office locations to hold face-to-face learning events, and offering more distance learning events. Many of these participants also noted the need for regional and CO staff to be involved in designing and delivering learning events.
Improve the relevance of offerings for participants. Sixteen comments provided advice on how to increase the relevance of learning events, usually through including concrete examples from Bank operations. Five of these participants also noted that relevance could be improved simply by providing a better description of the target audience so that staff would know which events were appropriate according to their levels and interests.
4.29 Suggestions from participants provided some guidance on how better to address staff demand for learning, particularly when considered in combination with the closed- ended survey ratings, the available data on learning activities, and the insights provided by managers and learning coordinators (appendix C). Conclusions and recommendations for ESSD's learning program based on all data sources are presented in the next chapter.
16Respondents were prompted to list up to three suggestions for orientation sessions and three suggestions for training courses; however, similar types of responses appeared in both categories.
25  5. CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS
5.1 ESSD has increasingly integrated staff learning and knowledge sharing since FY04 and developed KSL structures, processes, and capacity to support a next generation learning program. These initiatives yielded a comprehensive program with coordinated series of learning events supplemented by KSL products and resources. Despite these efforts, the program was not adequately supported by the existing staff learning infrastructure at the Bank in FY05 and FY06 and was not well understood by network managers and staff. The findings and recommendations of this evaluation, summarized below, identify some steps that the KSL team, the CLO, and the KLB can implement to optimize learning provided by the new Sustainable Development network.
SUGGESTED ACTIONS FOR THE KSL TEAM
5.2 To increase the synergy and efficiency of staff learning across all network units, ESSD established centralized structures and processes to shape the overall learning program. The result for FY05 and FY06 was a consistent program, with few differences in quality, relevance, or effectiveness across sectors. Furthermore, the initiative to develop capacity among KSL staff in FY05 appeared to have contributed to a notable improvement in participants' assessments of quality in FY06. The findings of this evaluation did not signal the need for major changes to the current model but instead indicated areas for improvement within it. Recommended actions for the KSL team are presented below in the order in which they should occur.
Knowledge and learning results framework
5.3 ESSD's KSL team held strategic planning meetings each year to set priorities for the overall program, but this evaluation did not produce evidence that the program was aligned with business objectives or effectively addressing staff demands for learning. The lack of clear objectives for the learning program, detailed information on how planned activities support learning objectives, or data on the delivery and content of learning activities prevented a systematic assessment of how well the program's offerings supported the strategic priorities of ESSD's business plan.
5.4 The KSL team should establish measurable objectives for its learning program with associated indicators to gauge how well the program is addressing network business needs. The learning plan template and toolkit provided by the CLO's office has fostered some improvements for FY07, but the translation from the network's strategic priorities to specific learning objectives can be strengthened. In what ways should the skills and knowledge of staff be developed to achieve the network's priorities? Among which groups or levels of staff? How will SDN assess the degree to which learning objectives have been achieved? The KSL team must refine its learning plan in collaboration with
26  the CLO's office (discussed below) to create a useful tool for designing and delivering the learning program and assessing its success vis-à-vis strategic priorities.
Data management
5.5 Input from sector managers and program participants suggested that many of the program's stakeholders did not have an accurate understanding of what learning events and products ESSD offered. A majority of participants did not find the LMS to be an effective resource for finding information about planned learning activities in FY06, either because staff did not know how to use the system appropriately or because providers did not enter consistent and desirable details about upcoming events.
5.6 To improve the quality and use of the LMS, the KSL team should establish standard guidelines for entering learning activity data and a quality assurance process to support improved data management. The LMS is still a relatively new data system at the Bank, and learning teams must provide feedback and support to ensure that this is a useful tool to facilitate and track staff learning. Recommendations for continuing to refine the data quality and use of the LMS include:
Establish clear guidelines for all providers of staff learning for what types of events or programs should be recorded in the LMS. The focus on combining learning and knowledge sharing and delivering coherent programs rather than isolated events may have resulted in confusion about which activities should appear in the LMS. The KSL team should create standards for recording events to promote consistency across the network's learning program.
Organize and present details about learning events so that staff can easily choose and schedule activities most appropriate for them. At minimum, the system should identify events by theme or issue, list the date(s) or estimated period when the events will occur, indicate the general format or event type, stipulate the level of expertise required by participants, and describe the expected scope or depth of the content. Specification of expected outcomes would also be desirable.
Clarify accountability for data quality and institute a quality assurance process. The LMS can be a reliable tool to facilitate and track staff learning only if learning coordinators or course providers enter consistent data on learning activities and participation. Appropriate use of the system is in everyone's best interest, both to link staff with optimal learning programs and to provide the learning team with data on learning provision and participation over time. The KSL team should therefore clarify who is responsible for entering data on learning events and establish a system for checking data quality (at least for a sample) and following up as needed.
Test usability of system and provide feedback to the LMS administrator. The new system is intended to serve learning needs, and the KSL team should ensure that the system is a useful tool for the network. Key steps could include actively testing the system to monitor functions and improvements or soliciting feedback
27  on usability from a sample of staff. Constructive input from users is necessary to guide the CLO's office in refining the LMS to be an optimal data system.
5.7 Efforts to improve the quality of data in the LMS should be supplemented with a clear communications strategy to educate staff and managers better about their network's learning program and how the LMS can identify opportunities to address staff learning needs.
Accountability and continuous improvement
5.8 ESSD already had various structures and strategies in place to incorporate evaluation findings into the planning, design, and delivery of learning activities. The KSL team had a specialist responsible for participant assessments of most network learning activities. The team had also conducted regular needs assessments and selected certain programs for tracer studies. Despite this promising existing infrastructure for evaluating and informing program activities, this study did identify some areas where ongoing monitoring is needed. For example, program satisfaction was notably higher for staff based in the anchor compared with those in the regions.
5.9 In keeping with its knowledge and learning results framework, the KSL team should clarify responsibilities and establish a cycle for incorporating improvements into its learning plan and monitoring program improvements. This evaluation provided a one-time snapshot of subgroups' satisfaction with the program and suggestions for improvements. How will the team ensure that this information informs program improvements over time? The differences in ratings between regional staff and anchor staff noted above could well be explained by the emphasis on developing KSL capacity during this time period. The differences might be a temporary result of the reinvention of the learning program or they could signal a more significant problem, so the participation and satisfaction of regional staff should be monitored systematically in light of these findings. Similarly, the KSL team should have a system for disseminating and applying best practices for learning providers, such as the guidance from participants that learning events should include concrete examples from Bank operations.
SUGGESTED ACTIONS FOR THE CLO AND THE KLB
5.10 The CLO and the KLB should also take steps to ensure that Bank and network staff engage in effective professional and technical learning opportunities. Areas for improvement highlighted by evaluation findings suggest a need to refine the LMS and educate users and to foster a learning community that collaborates and shares promising practices.
Improvements to centralized systems
5.11 The CLO's office should continue refining processes and systems that support VPUs in developing and delivering learning programs, notably the LMS and the tools and guidance for developing learning plans. ESSD's learning plans for FY05 and FY06 did not identify measurable objectives or indicators for assessing how learning offerings addressed strategic priorities, and this may be an area in which the CLO can take the lead
28  and encourage attention to results rather than just activities and outputs. The CLO should continue to provide a learning plan toolkit and develop specific examples to support SDN (and all SLCs) in creating a useful tool. As part of its regular review of learning plans, the CLO's office should require clear evidence that proposed activities are aligned to networks' strategic priorities. In addition, the KLB must continue to prioritize action steps related to the LMS. These include working with VPUs to address system weaknesses (as discussed above), clarify definitions for event types, improve data integrity, and continue to educate the Bank community on using the LMS.
Fostering a community of practice
5.12 The KLB should promote and facilitate collaboration and information sharing to support the new results agenda for staff learning. By its existence, the KLB signals the value of centralizing some learning functions. This body can capitalize on opportunities for greater efficiency by establishing systems for sharing knowledge and tools across VPUs. A platform is needed to supplement KLB meetings by providing resources such as:
promising examples for designing the new results framework, such as excerpts from learning plans;
successful models of on-the-job training or descriptions and/or evaluation findings from innovative learning programs;
discussion threads on experiences with and improvements to the LMS (or other relevant processes and systems);
tools or processes proven by some VPU(s) to be useful in assessing learning needs;
reports on VPUs' learning efforts or major initiatives (such as the comprehensive staff learning needs assessment conducted by ESSD); and
apparent gaps in the learning opportunities provided to VPU staff that could signal areas for cross-VPU collaboration.
A simple electronic learning community could provide an enabling environment both for strengthening the centralized learning functions entrusted to the KLB and for adapting tools and processes where helpful for supporting the Bank's decentralized business and staff.
5.13 ESSD's learning program in FY05 and FY06 challenged the boundaries of staff learning at the Bank. Clarifying the program's objectives and strengthening the connections between the network's program and the centralized functions embodied by the KLB will increase the program's visibility and definition for all staff and provide data for systematically monitoring and improving network-related learning and knowledge sharing over time.
29  30  APPENDIX A: METHODOLOGY
This evaluation focused on the overall ESSD learning program in FY05 and FY06 to help the network understand its accomplishments vis-à-vis staff learning and improve the relevance, effectiveness, and impact of the ESSD learning program. The goal of the evaluation was to provide the KLB and the network with information to guide strategic decisions about staff learning programs. The WBIEG team used a mixed-method approach and relied on three types of data: existing data on ESSD learning activities and Bank staff, focus group and interview data from sector managers and members of the ESSD learning team, and survey responses from participants of the ESSD learning program.
DATA COLLECTION
Existing data. Human Resources (HR) provided lists of ESSD-mapped staff as of June 2005 and June 2006. These lists provided demographic variables and were matched with lists of ESSD participants collected through Business Warehouse (BW) in FY05 and through LMS in FY06. The team compiled the pool of ESSD participants for FY05 and FY06 by including staff who had participated in at least one event in either year. Overall, the existing data provided an overview of the events offered, allowed the team to explore patterns of participation among ESSD staff and staff outside the network, and supported analysis on the potential role of demographic variables for participation and satisfaction.
Focus group and interview data. All members of the ESSD learning team were invited to a focus group discussion in March 2006, and eight members attended. This session explored the processes used by the learning team to develop the learning plan and design learning events and examined perceptions about the quality and effectiveness of the program in FY05. Three focus groups were also held for sector managers, with a total of eleven managers participating. Eight managers who had not attended any focus groups participated in individual interviews. The selection of focus groups and interviews ensured that managers from all sectors and regions provided reflections on what skills and knowledge their staff need, how learning needs are assessed, and the quality and effectiveness of the overall learning program.
Survey data. The study included a web-based surveys of ESSD-mapped participants in ESSD events. The participant survey explored perceptions about the quality and effectiveness of the learning program, motivations for participating, and suggestions for future improvements. The pool of ESSD participants (described under existing data) totaled 660 staff. Of these, the team randomly selected 400 and contacted these individuals via email to direct them to the survey (August to October 2006). A total of 200 staff responded to the survey for a response rate of 51 percent.17 The profile of respondents is similar to that of the overall population of ESSD participants as shown in table 1.

ANALYSIS
The team relied on basic descriptive statistics for this study, mainly frequencies, cross tabulations, t tests, and correlations. Quantitative data available from HR, BW, and LMS allowed the team to explore the characteristics of ESSD staff and ESSD learning activities. The data collected through web surveys were merged with the demographic variables of participants to explore the potential influence of subgroup categories on participation or satisfaction. The analysis focused on differences based on location (headquarters versus country office), grade level, sector, VPU, and length of time at the Bank. Differences in means and percentages were reported only if they were significant at the p<0.05 level. Qualitative data collected through interviews, focus groups, and open-ended survey questions were sorted according to major themes and used to understand or explain better the results of the quantitative analysis.
LIMITATIONS

doc.abstracts: Effective staff learning is of critical importance to the World Bank to ensure that personnel have the best mix of skills, behaviors, experience, and technical expertise for achieving the Bank's business objectives. At the request of the Knowledge and Learning Board (KLB), the World Bank Institute Evaluation Group (WBIEG) evaluated the staff learning program provided by the Environmentally and Socially Sustainable Developments (ESSDs) network in FY05 and FY06. The study focused on helping the network understand its accomplishments vis-a vis staff learning, address weaknesses, and improve the relevance, effectiveness, and impact of ESSDs learning program in the future.
